title: Contributing to GeoPressureR
text: outlines propose change GeoPressureR.

title: Contributing to GeoPressureR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to GeoPressureR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to GeoPressureR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("Rafnuss/GeoPressureR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to GeoPressureR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Raphaël Nussbaumer. Author, maintainer. Mathieu Gravey. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: nussbaumer2022a nussbaumer2022b nussbaumer2022c
code: @Misc{,   title = {Global positioning with animal-borne pressure sensors},   author = {Raphael Nussbaumer and Mathieu Gravey and Martins Briedis and Felix Liechti},   doi = {10.21203/rs.3.rs-1381915/v2},   url = {https://doi.org/10.21203/rs.3.rs-1381915/v2},   pages = {1--18},   year = {2022}, } @Misc{,   title = {Inferring bird’s trajectory from multi-sensor geolocators and remote sensing with a graphical model},   author = {Raphael Nussbaumer and Mathieu Gravey and Martins Briedis and Felix Liechti},   doi = {10.21203/rs.3.rs-1693751/v1},   url = {https://doi.org/10.21203/rs.3.rs-1693751/v1},   pages = {1--32},   year = {2022}, } @Manual{,   title = {GeoPressureR: Location from Reanalysed Pressure},   author = {Raphael Nussbaumer and Mathieu Gravey},   url = {https://github.com/Rafnuss/GeoPressureR},   year = {2022}, }

title: Global Positioning by Atmospheric Pressure
text: GeoPressureR R package help researchers determine position bird based data retrieved multi-sensor geolocators. main novelty package match atmospheric pressure measurements weather reanalysis database (ERA-5) produce probability maps position. addition, use graphical model combine pressure, light, acceleration windspeed data trajectory model bird.

title: Global Positioning by Atmospheric Pressure
text: GeoPressureManual great place start learning can determine trajectory bird. Using example Great Reed Warbler (18LX), user guide takes step analysis detail.

title: Global Positioning by Atmospheric Pressure
text: familiar method want start study, suggest use GeoPressureTemplate, github template repository provides standard code structure analysis. Using standardized code structure output allow code sharing troubleshooting, data archiving, work reproducibility, easy check reviewers.

title: Global Positioning by Atmospheric Pressure
text: best way get help use github discussions. Contributions code follow Contributor Code Conduct.

what: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
title: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
text: Search pairs sunset, sunrise correspond given light threshold. Function inspired findTwilights package TwGeos.

title: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
code: find_twilights(light, threshold = NA, shift_k = NA)

title: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
text: light dataframe columns date obs sequence sample times (POSIXct) light levels recorded tag. threshold light threshold defines twilight. provided, uses first light (.e, obs>0). shift_k shift middle night compared 00:00 UTC (seconds). provided, take middle nights.

title: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
text: data.frame columns twilight (date-time twilights) rise (logical)

title: Returns twilights for each day based on a threshold of light — find_twilights
code: pam <- pam_read(   pathname = system.file("extdata/0_PAM/18LX", package = "GeoPressureR"),   crop_start = "2017-06-20", crop_end = "2018-05-02" ) twl <- find_twilights(pam$light) head(twl) #>               twilight  rise #> 16 2017-07-27 03:05:00 FALSE #> 1  2017-07-27 18:25:00  TRUE #> 17 2017-07-28 03:20:00 FALSE #> 2  2017-07-28 18:40:00  TRUE #> 18 2017-07-29 03:00:00 FALSE #> 3  2017-07-29 18:50:00  TRUE

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
text: function return list four morphological information necessary construct power curve: mass, wing span, wing aspect ratio body frontal area.

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
code: flight_bird(   species_name,   mass = NA,   wing_span = NA,   wing_aspect = NA,   wing_area = NA,   body_frontal_area = NA )

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
text: species_name Scientific name species mass Mass bird kilogram. wing_span Wing span meter. wing_aspect Wing aspect ratio (unit). wing_area Wing area meter square. body_frontal_area Body frontal area meter square.

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
text: List containing mass, wing span, wing aspect ratio body frontal area.

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
text: variables missing, query doi:10.6084/m9.figshare.16586228.v5 AVONET database using scientific name Clements Checklist.

title: Construct bird morphology — flight_bird
code: # Using AVONET dataset flight_bird("Acrocephalus arundinaceus") #> $species_name #> [1] "Acrocephalus arundinaceus" #>  #> $mass #> [1] 0.03 #>  #> $body_frontal_area #> [1] 0.001498105 #>  #> $wing_span #> [1] 0.242256 #>  #> $wing_aspect #> [1] 7.114714 #>  # Using AVONET dataset + custom values flight_bird("Acrocephalus arundinaceus", wing_aspect = 8) #> $species_name #> [1] "Acrocephalus arundinaceus" #>  #> $mass #> [1] 0.03 #>  #> $body_frontal_area #> [1] 0.001498105 #>  #> $wing_span #> [1] 0.242256 #>  #> $wing_aspect #> [1] 8 #>  # Import your own bird. You will need mass, and at least two of wing_span, # wing_aspect or wing_area. flight_bird("custum_bird", mass = 1, wing_span = 1, wing_aspect = 4) #> $species_name #> [1] "custum_bird" #>  #> $mass #> [1] 1 #>  #> $body_frontal_area #> [1] 0.0129 #>  #> $wing_span #> [1] 1 #>  #> $wing_aspect #> [1] 4 #>

title: Power curve — flight_power
text: Compute mechanical power (W =J/s) required specific bird flying given airspeed m/s. bird created flight_bird().

title: Power curve — flight_power
code: flight_power(as, bird)

title: Power curve — flight_power
text: airspeed m/s bird list basic morphological trait necessary: mass, wing span, wing aspect ratio body frontal area. best practice create bird flight_bird().

title: Power curve — flight_power
text: mechanical power Watt (Joule/seconds) corresponding airspeed

title: Power curve — flight_power
code: bird <- flight_bird("Acrocephalus arundinaceus") airspeed <- seq(0, 30) power <- flight_power(airspeed, bird) plot(airspeed, power, xlab = "Airspeed [m/s]", ylab = "Mechanical Power [W]", type = "l")

title: Movement model — flight_prob
text: Compute mechanical power required specific bird flying given airspeed km/h. bird (created flight_bird())

title: Movement model — flight_prob
code: flight_prob(   speed,   method = "gamma",   shape = 7,   scale = 7,   location = 40,   bird = NA,   fun_power = function(power) {      (1/power)^3  },   low_speed_fix = 15 )

title: Movement model — flight_prob
text: speed airspeed groundspeed km/h method method used convert speed probability ("gamma", "logis" "power") shape parameter gamma distribution scale parameter gamma logistic distribution location parameter logistic distribution bird list basic morphological trait necessary: mass, wing span, wing aspect ratio body frontal area. best practice create bird flight_bird(). fun_power function taking power single argument returning probability low_speed_fix speed probability remains . parameter used allow short flight covering small distance.

title: Movement model — flight_prob
text: Probability values corresponding speed provided

title: Movement model — flight_prob
code: speed <- seq(1, 120) low_speed_fix <- 20 # minimum speed allowed prob <- flight_prob(speed,   method = "gamma", shape = 7, scale = 7,   low_speed_fix = low_speed_fix ) plot(speed, prob,   type = "l", xlab = "Groundspeed [km/h]", ylab =     "Probability" ) abline(v = low_speed_fix)  bird <- flight_bird("Acrocephalus arundinaceus") prob <- flight_prob(speed, method = "power", bird = bird) plot(speed, prob, type = "l", xlab = "Airspeed [km/h]", ylab = "Probability")

what: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
text: function returns stationary period (1) map mismatch pressure measured geolocator ERA5 pressure database (2) map altitude threshold using fine scale digital elevation model.

title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
code: geopressure_map(pressure, extent, scale = 10, max_sample = 250, margin = 30)

title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
text: pressure Pressure data.frame PAM logger. data.frame needs contains date POSIXt, obs hPa, sta_id grouping observation measured stationary period isoutlier logical label observation need ignored. best practice use pam_read() pam_sta() build data.frame. extent Geographical extent map query list ordered North, West, South, East  (e.g. c(50,-16,0,20)). scale Number pixel per 1° latitude-longitude. instance, scale = 10 resolution 0.1° (~10km) 4 resolution 0.25° (~30km). avoid interpolating ERA5 data, scale smaller 10. Read scale Google earth Engine documentation. max_sample computation maps performed max_sample datapoints pressure reduce computational time. samples randomly (uniformly) selected timeserie. margin margin used threshold map accept measurement error. unit meter. (1hPa~10m)

title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
text: List raster map

title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
text: maps generated Google Earth Engine via Pressure map entry point GeoPressure API. computation performed function consists following: Send query generate Google Earth Engine (GEE) url code producing maps stationary periods separately. Download read geotiff maps raster. maps stationary period returned two layers: mismatch input pressure timeseries reanalysis one location. computed mean square error (MSE) mean error removed. mean error removed assume specific altitude geolocator, thus allowing altitudinal shift pressure timeserie. proportion datapoint input pressure timeseries corresponding altitude value fall within min max ground elevation found location. altitude value geolocator pressure timeseries computed barometric formula accounting temporal variation pressure (surface-pressure) temperature (2m-temperature) based ERA5 data. min max ground elevation pixel computed SRTM-90.

title: Request and download mismatch and threshold maps of pressure — geopressure_map
code: # See `pam_sta()` for generating pam if (FALSE) { pressure_maps <- geopressure_map(   pam$pressure,   extent = c(50, -16, 0, 23),   scale = 4,   max_sample = 250,   margin = 30 ) pressure_maps_1 <- pressure_maps[[1]] } pressure_maps_1 <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/1_pressure/", "18LX_pressure_maps_1.rda",   package = "GeoPressureR" )) #> Loading required package: raster #> Loading required package: sp raster::metadata(pressure_maps_1) #> $sta_id #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nb_sample #> [1] 211 #>  #> $max_sample #> [1] 250 #>  #> $temporal_extent #> [1] "2017-07-27 01:00:00 UTC" "2017-08-04 19:00:00 UTC" #>  #> $margin #> [1] 30 #>  raster::plot(pressure_maps_1,   main = c("Mean Square Error", "Mask of pressure") )

what: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
title: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
text: Find location highest value map return path data.frame containing latitude longitude. interp can used interpolate unrealistic position short stationary period based position longer ones. interpolation assumes first last stationary period can safely estimated probability map.

title: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
code: geopressure_map2path(map, interp = 0, format = "lonlat")

title: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
text: map List raster containing probability map stationary period. metadata map needs include start end time stationary period . interp position stationary period shorter interp replace linear average position (days) . format One "lonlat", "ind", "arr.ind". return path lon-lat indices

title: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
text: data.frame position containing latitude (lat), longitude (lon) stationary period id (sta_id) column. Optionally, indexes requested, return. need use .max(.matrix(raster)) .max(raster) get correct location.

title: Return the most likely path from a probability map — geopressure_map2path
code: # See `geopressure_prob_map()` for generating pressure_prob pressure_prob_1 <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/1_pressure/", "18LX_pressure_prob_1.rda",   package = "GeoPressureR" )) geopressure_map2path(list(pressure_prob_1)) #>      lon    lat sta_id #> 1 17.125 48.875      1

title: Compute probability raster — geopressure_prob_map
text: function convert raster normalized MSE altitude threshold \(z_{thr}\) computed geopressure_map() probability map , \(p = \exp \left(-w \frac{MSE}{s} \right) \left[z_{thr}>thr \right],\) \(s\) standard deviation pressure \(thr\) threshold. auto-correlation timeseries accounted equation, use log-linear pooling weight \(w=\log(n) - 1\), \(n\) number data point timeserie. operation describe doi:10.21203/rs.3.rs-1381915/v1 .

title: Compute probability raster — geopressure_prob_map
code: geopressure_prob_map(   pressure_maps,   s = 1,   thr = 0.9,   fun_w = function(n) {      log(n)/n  } )

title: Compute probability raster — geopressure_prob_map
text: pressure_maps List raster built geopressure_map(). s Standard deviation pressure error. thr Threshold percentage data point outside elevation range considered possible. fun_w function taking number sample timeseries used compute probability map return log-linear pooling weight (see GeoPressureManual | Probability aggregation )

title: Compute probability raster — geopressure_prob_map
text: List probability raster map

title: Compute probability raster — geopressure_prob_map
code: # See `geopressure_map()` for generating pressure_maps if (FALSE) { pressure_prob <- geopressure_prob_map(   pressure_maps,   s = 0.4,   thr = 0.9 ) pressure_prob_1 <- pressure_prob[[1]] } pressure_prob_1 <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/1_pressure/", "18LX_pressure_prob_1.rda",   package = "GeoPressureR" )) raster::metadata(pressure_prob_1) #> $sta_id #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nb_sample #> [1] 211 #>  #> $max_sample #> [1] 250 #>  #> $temporal_extent #> [1] "2017-07-27 01:00:00 UTC" "2017-08-04 19:00:00 UTC" #>  #> $margin #> [1] 30 #>  raster::plot(pressure_prob_1,   main = "Probability",   xlim = c(5, 20), ylim = c(42, 50) )

what: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
title: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
text: function return surface atmospheric pressure timeseries ERA5 queried location.

title: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
code: geopressure_ts(   lon,   lat,   pressure = NULL,   end_time = NULL,   start_time = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
text: lon Longitude query (-180° 180°). lat Latitude query (0° 90°). pressure Pressure list PAM logger dataset list (optional). end_time pressure provided, end_time define ending time timeserie POSIXlt. start_time pressure provided, start_time define starting time timeserie POSIXlt. verbose Display () progress query (logical).

title: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
text: data.frame containing timeserie ERA5 pressure (date, pressure) well longitude  latitude (different water). pressure provided, return data.frame pressure altitude pressure0.

title: Request and download surface pressure timeseries at location — geopressure_ts
text: supply pressure (time) geolocator \(P_{gl}\), function additionally return altitude geolocator sea level \(z_{gl}\) using barometric equation, $$ z_{{gl}}(x)=z_{ERA5}(x) + \frac{T_{ERA5}(x)}{L_b}  \left( \frac{P_{gl}}{P_{ERA5}(x)} \right)^{\frac{RL_b}{g M}-1},$$ \(z_{ERA}\), \(T_{ERA}\) \(P_{ERA}\) respectively correspond ground level elevation, temperature 2m ground level pressure ERA5, \(L_b\)  standard temperature lapse rate, \(R\) universal gas constant, \(g\) gravity constant  \(M\) molar mass air. See information GeoPressureAPI documentation. timeseries response time supply, otherwise, return hourly basis start_time end_time. location query water, location moved closest onshore location. able compare temporal variation retrieved pressure ERA5 \(P_{ERA}\) geolocator pressure \(P_{gl}\), function also return ERA pressure normalized geolocator mean pressure measurement pressure0. $$ P_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})[t] = \left( P_{ERA5}(\boldsymbol{x})[t]-P_{gl}[t]\right) - \left( \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} P_{ERA5}(\boldsymbol{x})[]-P_{gl}[] \right).$$ See GeoPressureManual | Probability aggregation  information meaning value.

what: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
title: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
text: function runs parallel geopressure_ts() based path pressure timeserie. uses sta_id match pressure timeserie request position path.

title: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
code: geopressure_ts_path(path, pressure, include_flight = FALSE, verbose = TRUE)

title: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
text: path data.frame position containing latitude (lat), longitude  (lon) stationary period id (sta_id) column. pressure Pressure list PAM logger dataset list. include_flight Extend request also query pressure altitude previous /next flight. Flights defined sta_id=0. Accept Logical vector -1 (previous flight), 0 (stationary) /1 (next flight). (e.g. include_flight=c(-1, 1) search flight stationary period). Note next previous flights defined +/1 sta_id value (previous/next sta_id value). verbose Display () progress queries (logical).

title: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
text: List data.frame containing stationary period, date, pressure, altitude (geopressure_ts()).

title: Query the timeserie of pressure from a path and geolocator pressure — geopressure_ts_path
text: can include previous /next flight period query. typically useful estimate flight altitude greater precision. position path water, moved closest point onshore explained geopressure_ts().

what: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
title: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
text: GeoPressureViz shiny app designed helps visualize overall trajectory bird well step--step move. Learn GeoPressureViz GeoPressureManual | GeoPressureViz demo Great Reed Warbler (18LX).

title: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
code: geopressureviz(   pam,   static_prob,   pressure_prob = NA,   light_prob = NA,   static_prob_marginal = NA,   pressure_prob_thr = NA,   pressure_prob_mismatch = NA,   pressure_timeserie = NA,   lauch_browser = TRUE )

title: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
text: pam PAM logger dataset list pam$sta computed. See pam_read() pam_sta(). static_prob List raster containing probability map stationary period. metadata static_prob needs include flight information next stationary period metadata flight. See GeoPressureManual | Static map . pressure_prob List raster containing probability map stationary period according pressure data. See GeoPressureManual | Pressure map . light_prob List raster containing probability map stationary period according light data. See GeoPressureManual | Light map . static_prob_marginal List raster containing probability map stationary period according graph output. See GeoPressureManual | Basic graph . pressure_prob_thr List raster containing probability map stationary period according threshold pressure data. See GeoPressureManual | Pressure map . pressure_prob_mismatch List raster containing probability map stationary period according mismatch pressure data. See GeoPressureManual | Pressure map . pressure_timeserie List data.frame containing least sta_id, date pressure0 lauch_browser true (default), app run browser, otherwise Rstudio

title: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
text: path modified app.

title: Start the GeoPressureViz shiny app — geopressureviz
code: if (FALSE) { load("data/1_pressure/18LX_pressure_prob.Rdata") load("data/2_light/18LX_light_prob.Rdata") load("data/3_static/18LX_static_prob.Rdata") geopressureviz(   pam = pam,   static_prob = static_prob,   pressure_prob = pressure_prob,   light_prob = light_prob,   pressure_timeserie = static_timeserie ) }

title: Add windspeed and airspeed — graph_add_wind

code: graph_add_wind(grl, pressure, filename, thr_as = Inf)

title: Add windspeed and airspeed — graph_add_wind
text: grl graph constructed graph_create() pressure pressure data PAM logger. data.frame needs contains date POSIXt obs hPa. best practice use pam_read() pam_sta() build data.frame. filename Character path find netCDF file. thr_as Threshold airspeed (km/h).

title: Add windspeed and airspeed — graph_add_wind
text: Graph list windspeed airspeed ws respectively (see graph_create() detail graph returned).

title: Add windspeed and airspeed — graph_add_wind
text: See GeoPressureManual | Wind graph explanations example download NetCDF files ERA-5.

title: Create graph — graph_create
text: function return graph representing trajectory bird based filtering triming probability maps provided.

title: Create graph — graph_create
code: graph_create(static_prob, thr_prob_percentile = 0.99, thr_gs = 150)

title: Create graph — graph_create
text: static_prob List raster containing probability map stationary period. metadata static_prob needs include flight information next stationary period metadata flight. thr_prob_percentile Threshold percentile (see details). thr_gs Threshold groundspeed (km/h)  (see details).

title: Create graph — graph_create
text: Graph list (see details).

title: Create graph — graph_create
text: final graph, keep likely node (position time) defined : 1. cumulative probability reach thr_prob_percentile stationary period. 2. average ground speed lower thr_gs km/h. graph returned list edges graph containing: s: source node (index 3d grid lat-lon-sta), t: target node (index 3d grid lat-lon-sta), gs: average ground speed required make transition (km/h) complex number representing E-W real S-N imaginary. ps: static probability target node, sz: size 3d grid lat-lon-sta, equipment: node(s) first sta (index 3d grid lat-lon-sta), retrieval: node(s) last sta (index 3d grid lat-lon-sta), flight_duration: list flight duration next sta hours, lat: list static_prob latitude cell center, lon: list static_prob longitude cell center, extent: raster geographical extent static_prob, resolution: raster res static_prob, temporal_extent: start end date time retrieved metadata static_prob. GeoPressureManual | Basic graph provided example prepare data function output function.

title: Download wind data — graph_download_wind
text: function download wind data ERA5 hourly pressure level Climate Data Store (CDS) ecmwfr R package.

title: Download wind data — graph_download_wind
code: graph_download_wind(   pam,   area,   sta_id = seq_len(nrow(pam$sta) - 1),   cds_key = Sys.getenv("cds_key"),   cds_user = Sys.getenv("cds_user"),   path = paste0("data/5_wind_graph/", pam$id, "/") )

title: Download wind data — graph_download_wind
text: pam PAM logger dataset list pam$sta computed. See pam_read() pam_sta(). area Geographical extent map query. Either raster (e.g. static_prob) list ordered North, West, South, East  (e.g. c(50,-16,0,20)). sta_id Stationary period identifier start flight query defined pam$sta. default, download flight. cds_key User (email address) used sign ECMWF data service. See wf_set_key(). cds_user Token provided ECMWF. See wf_set_key(). path Path store downloaded data.

title: Download wind data — graph_download_wind
text: path downloaded (requested file).

title: Download wind data — graph_download_wind
text: flight determined stationary periods classified pam$sta (see pam_classify()). request single file flight using exact time (hourly basis) pressure (altitude). make download efficient, wf_request_batch() used download wind file time (20 requests parallel). able download data Climate Data Store (CDS), need create account https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu. can save credential (cds_key cds_user) .Rprofile (see GeoPressureManual | Wind graph).

title: Read pam data — pam_read
text: Imports multi-sensor logger data folder (pathname) optionally crop specific date. *_file arguments matched using regex expression (e.g., "*.pressure" matches files extension pressure).

title: Read pam data — pam_read
code: pam_read(   pathname,   pressure_file = "*.pressure",   light_file = "*.glf",   acceleration_file = "*.acceleration",   crop_start = "1900-01-01",   crop_end = "2100-01-01",   id = NA )

title: Read pam data — pam_read
text: pathname path directory files stored pressure_file file pressure data. Extension must .pressure, .deg. light_file file light data. Extension must .glf, .lux NA absent. acceleration_file file acceleration data. Extension must .acceleration, .deg NA absent. crop_start Remove date date (UTC). crop_end Remove date date (UTC). id Unique identifier track. Default (NA) take part pressure_file character _ (e.g. 18LX 18LX_20180725.pressure).

title: Read pam data — pam_read
text: list data.frames pressure, light acceleration.

title: Read pam data — pam_read
text: current implementation can read files : Swiss Ornithological Institute (SOI)  (default) pressure_file = "*.pressure", light_file = "*.glf" acceleration_file = "*.acceleration" Migrate Technology pressure_file = "*.deg", light_file = "*.lux" acceleration_file = "*.deg" Create issue github data format supported yet.

title: Compute stationary periods — pam_sta
code: pam <- pam_read(   pathname = system.file("extdata/0_PAM/18LX", package = "GeoPressureR") ) pam <- trainset_read(pam,   pathname = system.file("extdata/1_pressure/labels", package = "GeoPressureR") ) pam <- pam_sta(pam) head(pam$pressure) #>                  date obs isoutlier sta_id #> 1 2017-07-27 00:00:00 989     FALSE      0 #> 2 2017-07-27 00:30:00 989     FALSE      1 #> 3 2017-07-27 01:00:00 990     FALSE      1 #> 4 2017-07-27 01:30:00 990     FALSE      1 #> 5 2017-07-27 02:00:00 989     FALSE      1 #> 6 2017-07-27 02:30:00 989     FALSE      1 head(pam$light) #>                  date obs sta_id #> 1 2017-07-27 00:00:00   0      0 #> 2 2017-07-27 00:05:00   0      1 #> 3 2017-07-27 00:10:00   0      1 #> 4 2017-07-27 00:15:00   0      1 #> 5 2017-07-27 00:20:00   0      1 #> 6 2017-07-27 00:25:00   0      1

title: Path to data.frame — path2df
text: function basically duplicate location position start end time stationary period.

title: Path to data.frame — path2df
code: pam <- pam_read(   pathname = system.file("extdata/0_PAM/18LX", package = "GeoPressureR") ) pam <- trainset_read(pam,   pathname = system.file("extdata/1_pressure/labels", package = "GeoPressureR") ) pam <- pam_sta(pam) pressure_prob_1 <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/1_pressure/", "18LX_pressure_prob_1.rda",   package = "GeoPressureR" )) path <- geopressure_map2path(list(pressure_prob_1)) path2df(pam, path) #>      lon    lat track_id                time #> 1 17.125 48.875     18LX 2017-07-27 00:00:00 #> 2 17.125 48.875     18LX 2017-08-04 19:50:00

title: Atmospheric Refraction — refracted

text: zenith zenith angle (degrees) adjust.

title: Atmospheric Refraction — refracted
text: vector zenith angles (degrees) adjusted atmospheric refraction.

title: Atmospheric Refraction — refracted
text: Given vector solar zeniths computed zenith, refracted calculates solar zeniths adjusted effect atmospheric refraction. unrefracted inverse refracted. Given (single) solar zenith adjusted effect atmospheric refraction, unrefracted calculates solar zenith computed zenith.

title: Solar Time and Declination — solar

text: tm vector POSIXct times.

title: Solar Time and Declination — solar
text: list containing following vectors. solar_time solar time (degrees) eqn_time equation time (minutes time) sin_solar_dec sine solar declination cos_solar_dec cosine solar declination

title: Solar Time and Declination — solar
text: solar time, equation time sine cosine solar declination calculated times specified tm using methods https://gml.noaa.gov/grad/solcalc/.

title: Solar Time and Declination — solar

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
text: Calculate solar zenith angle given times locations

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
code: zenith(sun, lon, lat)

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
text: sun list solar time declination computed solar. lon vector longitudes. lat vector latitudes.

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
text: vector solar zenith angles (degrees) given locations times.

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
text: zenith uses solar time declination calculated solar compute solar zenith angle given times locations, using methods https://gml.noaa.gov/grad/solcalc/.  function adjust atmospheric refraction see refracted.

title: Solar Zenith Angle — zenith
code: # Approx location of Sydney Harbour Bridge lon <- 151.211 lat <- -33.852 # Solar zenith angle for noon on the first of May 2000 # at the Sydney Harbour Bridge s <- solar(as.POSIXct("2000-05-01 12:00:00", "EST")) zenith(s, lon, lat) #> [1] 133.9373
